docs.lead_paragraph: An investigation led by the office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, announced last week, concluded that college-sponsored health insurance plans were shortchanging students, paying out far less in benefits than they collect in premiums. Here are excerpts of the comments posted by readers: My son's college offers a surprisingly spendy health plan. It was notably cheaper just to keep him on the plan offered by my husband's employer. Since the pool is made up of individuals in the prime of healthy youth, the price makes me suspicious.
docs.abstract: Excerpts from comments posted by readers about investigation by office of Attorney General Andrew Cuomo that concluded college-sponsored health insurance plans are shortchanging students (M)

docs.section_name: Education; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: If you listen to climate scientists -- and despite the relentless campaign to discredit their work, you should -- it is long past time to do something about emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. If we continue with business as usual, they say, we are facing a rise in global temperatures that will be little short of apocalyptic. And to avoid that apocalypse, we have to wean our economy from the use of fossil fuels, coal above all. But is it possible to make drastic cuts in greenhouse-gas emissions without destroying our economy?
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman article explores economic implications of taking action to thwart climate change; says that for world to embrace changes that benefit planet, there must be economic incentive to do so, as companies must see way to make money through change; asserts that consumers and companies must acknowledge that climate change is indeed reality and may need financial consequences like taxation to force climate-saving outcomes; warns that inaction will not benefit anyone economically or environmentally long-term and emphasizes key importance of political support for any wide-ranging climate change initiatives to succeed; drawings (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Bart Stupak, the anti-abortion Democrat from Michigan who was central to negotiating a compromise with the Obama administration in passing the health care bill in March, announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election. He said that his main legislative goal -- health care reform -- had been accomplished and that he was ready to "do other things." Even so, he has been under intense pressure from Tea Party supporters who opposed the health care overhaul and abortion opponents who said he betrayed their cause.

headline.main: Stupak's Abortion Deal and His Exit

docs.abstract: Is pressure from Tea Party supporters and abortion opponents the reason why Stupak is stepping down?
docs.snippet: Is pressure from Tea Party supporters and abortion opponents the reason why Stupak is stepping down?

docs.lead_paragraph: "I've been 'unofficially' told by the H.R. manager of my employer," wrote RG from Los Angeles, "that it will be cheaper for them to take the penalty than to continue insuring us." RG's question - whether it was true that "many, many companies will start dumping health insurance benefits" - was one of several we fielded last week about how the new health care reform law would affect small businesses. And though this query came from an employee, not an owner, of a large company, not a small one, clearly many entrepreneurs are also worried that they'll have to abandon group coverage.

headline.main: Why Most Firms Won't Drop Employee Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Economists do not anticipate big changes in employer-sponsored coverage after 2014, when much of the reform takes effect.
docs.snippet: Economists do not anticipate big changes in employer-sponsored coverage after 2014, when much of the reform takes effect.

docs.lead_paragraph: When news got out this morning that Representative Bart Stupak of Michigan would announce that he is not running for re-election in November, many on the right crowed that they had taken down someone who had not adhered strictly enough to their anti-abortion principles.
docs.abstract: The left and the right are both claiming credit for the decision of Representative Bart Stupak of Michigan not to seek re-election.
docs.snippet: The left and the right are both claiming credit for the decision of Representative Bart Stupak of Michigan not to seek re-election.
